info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued July 08 at 4:53PM MDT until July 08 at 8:45PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: The National Weather Service in Albuquerque has issued a * Flash Flood Warning for... The Cooks Peak and Morris Creak burn scar in... South Central Colfax County in northeastern New Mexico... * Until 845 PM MDT. * At 453 PM MDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain over the the northern part of the Cooks Peak Burn Scar and the Morris Creek Burn Scar. Up to 1.4 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. Excessive rainfall over the burn scar will impact Rayado Creek, Mores Creek, LaMaquina Creek, Ortega Creek, and Alona Creek downstream to the Cimarron River. The debris flow can consist of rock, mud, vegetation and other loose materials. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding in and around the Cooks Peak and Morris Creak Burn Scar. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of areas in and around the Cooks Peak and Morris Creak Burn Scar. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Rayado. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Runoff from rainfall will cause elevated water levels within vulnerable drainages in and downstream of the northern portion of the Cooks Peak fire burn area, as well as the old Morris Creek fire burn area. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles.
